description: From Middle English includen, borrowed from Latin inclūdere (“to shut in, enclose, insert”), from in- (“in”) + claudere (“to shut”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *kleh₂u- (“key, hook, nail”). Doublet of enclose. Displaced native Old English belūcan (“to include,” also “to shut in”).

entries.meaning: (programming) A piece of source code or other content that is dynamically retrieved for inclusion in another item.
examples: In the previous lesson, you learned how to use server-side includes, which enable you to easily include snippets of web pages within other web pages.

verbs.description: include (third-person singular simple present includes, present participle including, simple past and past participle included)

entries.meaning: To bring into a group, class, set, or total as a (new) part or member.
examples: I will purchase the vacation package if you will include car rental.

entries.meaning: To consider as part of something; to comprehend.
examples: The vacation package includes car rental.
Does this volume of Shakespeare include his sonnets?
I was included in the invitation to the family gathering.
up to and including page twenty-five
I could have here willingly ranged, but these straits wherein I am included will not permit.

entries.meaning: (programming) To use a directive that allows the use of source code from another file.
examples: You have to include the strings library to use this function.
